Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man in dull yellow jacket, trousers and cap, with a brown waistcoat, is hanging about in a corridor. A woman's face appears at an opening high up in the wall, with an X next to it.

Dialogue.Line: Citizen Cordo, District Four?
Yes?
Congratulations, Citizen. Your father ceased at one ten.
All was well?
A fine death. Body weight was eighty four kilos at termination.
I'm gratified.
Gatherer Hade is waiting for the death taxes.
Yes, I have them here.
Pay them at the Gatherer's office.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man in a fancy striped cloak, wearing a golden turban bearing a stylised sun with a face on it, is humming to himself whilst reading a scroll. Outside, Cordo rings the bell.

Dialogue.Line: Let him enter.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo enters, and walks nervously along a narrow path between two rows of rib-like arches.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Citizen. Death taxes? Not on the desk. It might scar.
Oh, it is wood, your honour.
Mmm, of a kind called ma-ho-gany. I don't suppose you've ever seen wood before, have you, Citizen?
No, never. But we learned about it at preparation centre. There was even a picture of a tree! A fine thing.
Simply a primitive way of producing oxygen. Thank the Company we have no need of trees on Pluto.
Praise the Company.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An underling hands a blue plastic sheet down to Hade.

Dialogue.Line: Is this your account, Citizen? I see you selected the golden death, with four mercy attendants.
Yes, your honour. I always pledged that when his death day came he would not suffer.
Compassion is a noble thing, Citizen. Also costly. A hundred and seventeen talmars.
One hundred and seven? No, it can't be.
See the account.
But there's a mistake. Eighty, they said. Eighty for the golden death.
The Collector recently raised death taxes seventeen percent.
I didn't know, your Honour.
It was bulletined.
But I didn't see it.
It is every citizen's duty to know the tax rates.
I've been working double shifts to earn the money.

Four mercy attendants is now a further eighteen talmars. Disposal fee ten talmars plus of course an ad valorum tax of ten percent. Total one hundred and thirty two talmars. It's all here, you see, and said we put your father's personal contribution of seven talmars. Only seven talmars, Citizen? Must have been a poor man.
He was a municipal servant for forty years, your Honour. He cleaned the walkways.
And then there's the recycling allowance on his death weight of eighty four kilos. That is eight talmars. Leaving a debt of a hundred and seventeen.
Please, I have only eighty six. It has taken me years to save it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hade picks up the pouch by its strap with his long staff of office.

Dialogue.Line: How do you propose to settle the thirty one talmars outstanding?
Well, I can't. Your Honour, I have nothing.
Taxes are the primary consideration, Citizen. I see that you are a D grade worker in the Foundry.
Yes, your Honour.
Fortunately, as the Gatherer, I have certain powers. I will encourage your supervisor to allow you increased output.
But, your Honour, I already work a double shift now! I have only my three hours sleep time away from the Foundry.
Twenty one hours a week. You must manage without sleep time until the debt is paid.
It will kill me!
Take your Q capsule.
But your Honour, the high medical tax on Q capsules!
Citizen Cordo, you complain too much. Thank the Company you're warm and fed.
Praise the Company.
You may go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hade returns to his scroll.

Dialogue.Line: I am gratified, your Honour.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Leela are playing chess, with K9 helping Leela.

Dialogue.Line: Queen to knight six.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela moves the black Queen.

Dialogue.Line: There? K9: Affirmative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes one of her bishops with one of his.

Dialogue.Line: Even simple one-dimensional chess exposes the limitations of the machine mind. K9: Bishop to queen six. Mistress!
There? K9: Affirmative. Check, master.
What? K9: Machine mind computes mate in six moves.
Rubbish!
Doctor!
Leela, keep still.
But Doctor, the
And shut up. I'm trying to concentrate. K9: Your move, master.
I know it's my move. Don't flash your eyes at me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor moves his King.

Dialogue.Line: Wrong square.
What? K9: Your king, master. Wrong square.
Really? Are you sure? K9: Affirmative.
Doctor, can I speak now?
What? All right, if you must. What is it?
Well, the column's stopped moving.
So?
It is not important?
What?!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaps to the console.

Dialogue.Line: We might have gone right through the time spiral! Why didn't you tell me?
I tried to but you wouldn't let me.
You didn't.
I did.
You didn't.
I did!
You didn't.
I did!
It's that confounded paint. It's always jamming things up. Stay calm. I'm going to materialise and take a reading.
Where are we?
We're still in the Solar System. Pluto?
Pluto?
Yes, Pluto. K9: Ninth planet. Was until the discovery of Cassius believed to be the outermost body in the system. It has a diameter of three thousand
Leela, tell your tin friend to shut up.
K9, you can tell me later. K9: Affirmative. It's distance from the Sun is
Shush.
Breathable atmosphere. That's wrong.
There are buildings.
Pluto's a lifeless rock. Leela? I think you and I should take a W A L K.
W A L K?
W-a-l-k. K9: Walk, mistress.
I know. K9: Ready, master.
No, no, no. You're not coming. You stay here. K9: Entreat, master.
No. K9: I'll be good.
No! Pluto's no place for a
I'm sorry, K9. We won't be long.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis has parked herself in the middle of an empty industrial site, with the bare metal bones of units behind them and gravel underfoot. It is apparently the top of a very tall building, actually the roof of the WD+HO Wills tobacco factory in Bristol.

Dialogue.Line: Quite warm. Around twenty degrees. Very humid.
It is like Earth, except that the air is scented.
It's all wrong. It shouldn't be like Earth. Unless, of course, the Sun's turned nova.
Doctor, look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They are actually on the roof of a very tall building.

Dialogue.Line: Fascinating.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He gets out his telescope.

Dialogue.Line: What an engineering achievement, eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo is walking across the flat roof. Leela taps the Doctor's arm.

Dialogue.Line: Don't joggle, Leela. Don't joggle. You can look in a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo climbs over a guard rail a little way away from them.

Dialogue.Line: Must have taken them centuries to build a city like that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela runs towards Cordo.

Dialogue.Line: Hey!
What?
Come down! Please, come back!
Don't touch him!
Doctor! Please, don't jump.
Magnificent view, isn't it. How high is this building?
A thousand metres.
A thousand metres? My. Are we interrupting something?
What would you say, Citizen?
Somehow I have the impression you're thinking of killing yourself.
It's the taxes.
What?
It's the taxes. I can't pay the taxes.
Oh, the taxes. My dear old thing, all you need is a wiley accountant. Would you care for a jelly baby? Hmm? Try one.
What?
They're rather good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Looks more like liquorice allsorts to me. As Cordo reaches towards the bag, Leela tips him back over the guard rail.

Dialogue.Line: Now, tell us about it. This is Leela, I'm the Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A woman in a golden catsuit walks up to Hade's desk.

Dialogue.Line: What is it, Marn?
Air space violation, your Honour.
District Four.
The data vibes also indicate illegal landing.
Hmm?
Block Forty.
Excellent. There's a fine of five hundred talmars on each count. Order my demon(?) immediately, Marn. We must apprehend the culprit.

Then there's the medical tax on Q-capsules, and work tax on extra hours, so I could never clear the debt. You see, the Company charges fifty percent compound interest on unpaid taxes. I'm only a grade D work unit, three talmars a shift. Three talmars. That's not enough.
What is he saying, Doctor? I do not understand.
He can't make ends meet. Probably too many economists in the government.
These taxes, they are like sacrifices to tribal gods?
Well, roughly speaking, but paying tax is more painful.
Then the people should rise up and slaughter their oppressors!
Well, if little Cordo's at all typical, they haven't any spirit left for fighting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A wailing noise fills the air.

Dialogue.Line: It's the Gatherer! Quick, run!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo runs, Leela follows.

Dialogue.Line: Run, Doctor! It's the Gatherer!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Finally the Doctor runs too. They duck through a small door into a roof access area.

Dialogue.Line: If we are caught up here, there is a fine of five talmars or a week in the Correction Centre.
What?
It is an offence! Only the executive grade is allowed in the light of the suns.
Suns?
Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Marn and Hade approach the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: How did it get here?
Oh, use your intelligence, Marn. We detected an air space violation. Clearly a sky freighter.
But what is it, your Honour?
Obviously a container. See the lock?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela has been keeping watch.

Dialogue.Line: He is trying to open the Tardis.
Pity K9 can't bark.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo is climbing down a ladder.

Dialogue.Line: Quick! Quick!
What is it?
We must get away.
For someone who wanted to commit suicide a few minutes ago, you seem very anxious not to be caught.
Death is easy. Perhaps you've never been in the Correction Centre, Citizen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor follows Cordo down the ladder.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Leela.
Hurry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A freight lift arrives.

Dialogue.Line: It's an intriguing case, Marn.
Your Honour, it's inconceivable. To flout so many regulations.
Exactly. I smell something very big. Perhaps another Kandor conspiracy.
What was that?
Oh yes, Kandor.
I never heard of it.

Yes, it wasn't made public at the time in case it gave others ideas. Kandor was an executive grade in Megropolis Four who falsified computer records for the enrichment of himself and his fellow conspirators. Altogether he defrauded the Company of millions of talmars.
Praise the Company. What happened to him?
He survived three years in the Correction Centre.
Three years? A record.
He was very strong.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Going down.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we going?
I don't know. Why did you run?
Well, he ran first.
That's no answer.
Why did you run?
I don't know. Odd, isn't it?
Perhaps everyone runs from the tax man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo nods.

Dialogue.Line: He says you're right.
I can easily trace the delivery and freighter records.
Whatever programme the freighter used will self destruct in print.
You mean the instruction will not be retained in records? But that's another illegal
Does the robber hesitate to break a window? We're not dealing here, Marn, with some snivelling tax defaulter. This is a carefully planned criminal enterprise.
To what end, your Honour?
To defraud the Company of its rightful revenues by smuggling contraband goods into the Megropolis. I see the magnitude of the offence astounds you.
Well, it's hard to believe such depths of criminality.

It exists, Marn. It exists. Despite the screening and the Preparation Centres and the air conditioning, criminal deviants occur in every generation. Enemies of the Company. On old Earth they had a saying. There's one rotten acorn in every barrel. We must find this filth, Marn. Find it and crush it.
The Company be praised. How should it be done?
I have a plan.
What's the hurry?
I must leave you here, Citizens.
What are you going to do?
Perhaps I can join the others.
Who are the others?
It is said they live in the Undercity. Outlaws, tax criminals, some who've escaped from the Correction Centre. Perhaps they will help me, if they exist.
If you are not sure they exist, how do you expect to find them?
I know the secret way to the Undercity. You see, my father was an E grade work unit. He cleaned the walkways all his life. He learned the secret.
We'll come with you.
I'm gratified, Citizens, but there may be danger.
No, I'm interested in this Undercity. Always like to get to the bottom of things.
Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A circular cut tunnel with steps going downwards \- into the Camden Town Deep Tube Shelters built for protection in WW2.

Dialogue.Line: But you don't understand, Citizens. My father looked in once. He said there is no light, nothing. It is not possible to imagine such a thing.
You mean it is dark.
What is dark?
Well, at night, when the sun has gone.
He means there's no night on this planet, Leela. That's why the concept of darkness frightens him.
But that is not possible. Every planet must have a night.
Not if the sidereal and axial rotation periods are the same, or if there's more than one sun.
There are six.
What, six suns on Pluto?
Well, everyone knows that. Each Megropolis was given its own sun.
In-station fusion satellites. Galileo would have been impressed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They reach the bottom. It is darker down here.

Dialogue.Line: Cordo?
Yes?
Which way?
Somewhere beyond this point there is a little grating in the ground.
Well, go on.
No, I can't. It's hard to see. All the light is fading.
Your eyes will soon grow accustomed to the darkness.
I didn't think it would be as bad as this. I must turn back.
Too late.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A raggedy man and woman are behind them, wielding weapons.

Dialogue.Line: Take your hand off that knife, Leela.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A third man comes down the steps. Everyone say Hi to Michael Keating, just before Blakes 7.

Dialogue.Line: Hello. You must be the others.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis door opens and K9 looks out.

Dialogue.Line: Master?
The tracker system is activated, your Honour.
So soon? Well done, Marn.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 is on the screen.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
I don't have to tell you, Marn.
We caught these three snooping around the service subway.
You did not catch us. We allowed you to escort us.
What are they?
They claim they're from another planet, Mandrell.
There's no life on the other planets.
Really? How many other planets have you been to?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mandrell knocks the Doctor down.

Dialogue.Line: Show courtesy to my rank, or I'll cut your skin off inch by inch.
I can see we're going to get on famously.
Descend to level forty two.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The lift obeys.

Dialogue.Line: Where are they from? He looks like an Ajack.
Do you think he's insulting me?
With a face like his? He would not dare.
No.
Let me get him, Doctor. I could cut his heart out.
Shush. We haven't come here to fight. We haven't come here to fight.
Why did you come here, then?
Because my new little chum here seemed unhappy about something.
The D grade?
Yes, the D grade.
He wishes to join your tribe.
Get him up.
I'll get him up. Come on, don't be frightened.
Light. Please, Doctor, let me see some light.
Fool, there's no light down here. Only that which we make ourselves.
Come on. Come on! We can make a few candles out of him. It's all he's good for, Mandrell.
Shut up. What's your name?
Citizen Cordo, District Four.
Foundry or smelting?
I'm a foundry work unit, your honour. Always respectable. All my life I've met the production quotas, paid my dues and taxes, praise the Company.
Stuff the Company. Mouth those mindless parties down here, Citizen Cordo, and you'll get your throat slit. So, you're in trouble with the Gatherer, eh?
Yes. I couldn't meet my father's death taxes. It was more than I was told, and I
It's always more than they tell you. I've heard the story a thousand times. You stay with us, you'll have to earn your keep.
Oh, yes, your honour, I'll work. Anything.
Work? Work, Cordo? Nobody works here. We go into the upper levels and steal what we need. Aye, and kill for our needs when necessary.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A woman grabs Leela's costume.

Dialogue.Line: This skin, it's real skin!
You touch me again and I'll fillet you!
A handy girl. Doctor?
Hmm?
You two may be of more use to us than I thought.
Well I'm delighted to. Oh, no, no, we're just tourists. We're not staying.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mandrell snaps his fingers, and the Doctor and Leela are surrounded by armed Others.

Dialogue.Line: On the other hand, it is quite cozy. Don't you think it's quite cozy here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 has made it down to the deep shelter, and is still on the monitor.

Dialogue.Line: It's turning into subway CT1.
How I dislike the lower levels. So very depressing.
The D grade work units have their dormer somewhere along there.
He's turned again, Marn. Where is it now?
It looks like one of the service subways, your Honour.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 arrives at an open grill in the floor and a ladder. A power cable is also running down into it.
Veet puts the finishing touches to a large ConSumCard in the name of Citizen Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: It is finished.
A thousand talmars?
It will do.
It'd better do. A little task for you, Doctor.
Oh, good.
Here's a ConSumCard we got of an Ajack. It's made out for a thousand talmars.
A thousand talmars. Stolen?
What do you think?
Stolen.
It hasn't been used, so it's not on the computer records.
None of us could us it. We don't look like Ajacks.
Hmm. What do these Ajacks look like, if I'm pretending to be one. I ask merely for information.
They're all miners. They live in Megropolis Three.
Do you know how to use a ConSumCard?
Er, computer microloaded, er, do you feed it into a reader?
At the ConSum Bank on subway thirty seven.
Subway thirty seven.
Cordo? You show the Doctor how to get there.
(sotto) Do not go, Doctor.
What? Suppose I refuse to go?
You'll die.
It was just a passing thought.
Well, here's another one in case you run off with our talmars. If you're not back by this time, the girl dies.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mandrell puts a marker against a thick candle. Probably a few hours. The Doctor and Cordo leave.
The Doctor and Cordo climb the ladder to where K9 is waiting.

Dialogue.Line: I couldn't breathe down there.
It was a bit stuffy, but unscented.
What is it?
Nothing, just an idea. K9. K9: Master.
Didn't I tell you to stay in the Tardis?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is no sound on the monitor. The Doctor scolds K9 and sends him off somewhere.

Dialogue.Line: An Ajack, by the stamp of him.
The other. The other I've seen somewhere before.
A D grade?
D grade. Hmm. Of course! He was here, only hours ago, whining for time to pay his taxes.
What would an Ajack want with those riff-raff of the Undercity?
Quick, put the tracker on the Ajack.
Your Honour, it's not possible. The tracker system is keyed to follow that machine.
You mean you've lost him.
We know the subways he's traversing. We can make physical contact.
No, too soon for that. I want to know more about this Ajack. By my ledger, I've got it, Marn!
Your Honour?
I know what they're smuggling. Arms.
Weapons?

Mmm. They were always an arrogant, unsettled lot, the Ajacks. The air conditioning isn't effective in the mines. It's long been recognised that if there's ever a rebellion against the Company, it will start among the Ajacks. Don't you see?
You mean he's smuggling arms to the Undercity?
Exactly. And if it's happening here, it's a talmar to a toffee it's happening in every Megropolis on Pluto.
What shall we do?
I must go to the Company palace and warn the Collector. We need the Inner Retinue to deal with this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo runs and hides as four men arrive with a gurney. They vent the gas from the cubicle, open it, help the Doctor out and wheel him away.

Dialogue.Line: Your friend the Doctor, he'd better hurry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The flame is almost level with the marker.

Dialogue.Line: Mandrell, when you kill her don't damage her too much.
Oh, what a tender heart, Veet.
I want those skins.
See how she begs for a gently death for you? So full of love and compassion.
Before I die, I'll see this rat hole ankle deep in blood. That is a promised thing.
By the Company, if Mandrell orders her killed, I won't be the first man on his feet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An extremely short-sighted bald man is scanning a printout barely a millimetre from his nose. He hits a red lever and presses buttons on his desk without taking his eyes off the figures. Hade enters.

Dialogue.Line: Your Highest, a thousand apologies for this intrusion.
(without looking up) ?? Hade. Time is money.
Ah, what a great truth, your Sublimity. A pearl of wisdom.
Get to the point.
I've grounds for believing, your Eminence, that there is a conspiracy among dissident Ajacks to foment armed rebellion against the Company, glory be to the Company.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Now the little man looks up.

Dialogue.Line: Interesting. What exactly do you know, Hade?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor wakes to the sound of someone who whistles through their teeth when they sleep. They are wearing strait-jackets.

Dialogue.Line: Don't try to speak yet, my friend. Valerium gas affects the throat.
Where?

Where are you? You're in the Correction Centre. This is the Induction Therapy Section. That means they sensitise areas of the brain and clear the neural pathways so that when we arrive in Physical, we feel the full benefit. It intensifies pain a thousand times.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor manages to sit up.

Dialogue.Line: How long have I been here?
They brought you in just as the trumpets were sounding second workshift. About an hour ago.
An hour.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor falls back.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you.
It's a pleasure.
Your time's up, girl.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He snuffs out the candle.

Dialogue.Line: Seize her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One man tries, and gets thrown across the room.

Dialogue.Line: The next one dies.
Take her, you cowardly scabs! Must I do it myself?
Oh, try, Mandrell. Prove you have a heart as big as your mouth.
Mandrell! Wait a minute. Give the Doctor some more time.
It's possible that D grade Cordo took the wrong subway. He's not too smart.
You craven gutten factory fodder. Are you frightened of a half-grown girl?
Take care, Mandrell.
Watch it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela dodges Mandrell's blows with his whip handle easily. Then Cordo enters.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor!
What?
They've got him!
What do you mean?
How did they get him?
At the ConSum Bank. Something went wrong. I don't know, maybe it was the card.
Veet!
The card was perfect.
Well, the alarm blew as soon as he got in there. He didn't stand a chance. I had to run.
It must have been the Doctor's fault. The card had never been used.
Where's the Doctor now, Cordo?
Security picked him up there right away. They must have been cruising that section.
What will they do to him?
He'll be in the Correction Centre by now.
What?
They don't waste time.
Not when he's defrauding the ConSum Bank.
That's high crime.
He'll get maximum.
Maximum what?
Correction, of course. That's what the Centre's for, correcting people. He won't live long after that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stands up.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
Going for a little hop. Good for the circulation. What did they get you for?
Curiosity.
That's a crime here?
Yes. I was an executive grade at the chemical plant in charge of PCM production. I got curious about some of the other products.
Go on.
Well, there were some tablets labelled For Official Use only, for the Gatherers and the other Company staff. I wondered what they were, so I took some.
Ah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor examines a wall panel with three coloured levers, and starts messing around with the parts of the equipment underneath them, pulling them out with his teeth.

Dialogue.Line: I felt completely different, as though I'd never really been alive until then.
So you carried on taking them?
Of course I did. I suppose they noticed the difference in me and kept watch. The MegroGuards came for me during my last sleep time.
What does PCM stand for?
Pentocyleinicmethylhydrane.
What?
You know something about chemistry?
Enough to recognise an anxiety inducing agent when I smell one.
No, no, it eliminates airborne infections.
That's what they tell you. It also eliminates freedom.
These cellar dwellers should be erased.
Indubitably, your Elevation. It's a question of manpower. I simply haven't got sufficient staff.
It is against Company policy to give supportive aid to the civil administration. We run a purely fiscal operation.
Your Pinnacle, a five percent increase in protection tax would repay the Company, its name be praised.
Good thinking, Hade. You tempt me.
There is also the consideration that any sustained unrest amongst the work units could damage profitability.
Productivity-wise, I agree. An ongoing insurrectionary situation would not be acceptable to my management. This fiscal period we're aiming for a seven percent increase in the gross planetary product.
An achievable target, your Colossus, only if there is no dissention. With increased manpower I could locate and destroy these anti-Company agents before any harm is done.
Half a division of my Inner Retinue. That's all I can spare.
I am gratified.
Also increase the daily PCM dosage three percent by volume as of now.
I
This interview is terminated.
Have the honour to remain, sir
Seventeen. Twenty.
Your humble and obedient servant. Yours etc etc.
Twenty two. Nineteen. Fourteen and twenty five.
What kind of men are you?
The kind that want to live.
If only six of you come with me to this Correction Centre, we can get the Doctor out.
Why should we risk our necks for him?
You sent him to the ConSum Bank and now he's in trouble you will not even help him.
There's nothing we can do.
How do you know when you will not even try?
Listen, fool, the Correction Centre is under the Palace itself.
What Palace?
What Palace? There's only one Palace.
It's where the Collector lives. They say he likes to hear the screams. That's why the Centre's there.
And that's why we won't raid it. Because it's guarded by him Inner Retinue and they've got things called guns. And what have we got?

You? You have nothing, Mandrell. No pride, no courage, no manhood. Even animals protect their own. You say to me you want to live. Well I'll say this to you. If you lie skulking in this black pit while the Doctor dies, then you will live, but without honour!
Someone silence the termagin. She's crazy.
I want just six of you to come with me. Now, who amongst you is a true man? You, Goudry.
Like Mandrell says, the guards are armed.
You? Will you come?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The rest of the Others turn away or stay quiet.

Dialogue.Line: I see. Not one of you. Then I shall go alone.
I'll come, Leela.
You, Cordo?
I know I'm not much help. I'm not brave and I can't fight, but, well, at least I can show you the way.
Cordo, you are the bravest man here. Come.
Tell me, Bisham, how do they spread the PCM through the atmosphere?
It's a high pressure system, Doctor. The PCM is volatilized through the vapour towers and the air conditioning system.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard enters.

Dialogue.Line: I should think so too. Do you know how long we've been sitting here without any attention at all? Do you know that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard picks up a piece of helmet style equipment and puts it over Bisham's head.

Dialogue.Line: I said, do you know how long we've been sitting here without any attention? Are you deaf or something? Is he deaf or something?
We don't count anymore. We're just material for processing.
Ah. Right. I'm glad he isn't deaf.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard pushes the Doctor back down onto the table and puts a helmet on him, too.

Dialogue.Line: I would have felt guilty. Don't leave it in too long, it goes frizzy.
I'm sorry our acquaintance was so brief, Doctor. It has been a pleasure meeting you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard pulls down two of the three levers on the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, that's all right, Bisham. We'll have another opportunity to talk. There's a lot you can tell me.
I'm afraid after this nobody remembers much.
I wouldn't touch that, if I were you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard reaches for the middle, red, lever.

Dialogue.Line: I said, I wouldn't touch that if I were you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard gets electrocuted and the equipment goes bang. Flames leap up inside the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure he wasn't deaf?
Detained? When was this? By whose order?
He was caught while frauding with a stolen ConSumCard. The MegroGuards have taken him to Correction.

Too soon, Marn. Too soon. Oh, we might squeeze the names of his accomplices out of him, but if they hear he's been arrested they'll take fright. Many of them must be Executive grades. They'll move to other Megropolises. We could be years tracking them down.
He's our only lead, your Honour.
Hmm. Have him released from Correction immediately.
What reason shall I give?
Tell them that Gatherer Hade orders the charge to be quashed.
And bring him here.
Exactly. We must lull any suspicions he may have.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela comes up the ladder.

Dialogue.Line: K9, what are you doing here? K9: Waiting, mistress.
Waiting for what? K9: The Doctor master ordered me to stay.
In the Tardis. You should not be here at all. K9: Affirmative.
Oh, K9, this is Cordo. Cordo, K9.
Yes, I've seen it before. What is it?
Well, he's a sort of friend. K9: Affirmative. Friend.
K9, are your batteries fully charged? K9: All my systems are at maximum function, mistress.
Then you had better come with us. I think we might be needing you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Technicians are repairing the equipment.

Dialogue.Line: I wonder how long it'll take them to fix that?
Not long, I'm afraid. There's no need to hurry on our account. Take a break or something. Have a cup of tea. Have some jelly babies. There are some in my coat pocket. No? All right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Marn enters with a guard.

Dialogue.Line: Hello.
This is the one. Untie him.
Ah, thank you. I don't like this jacket. Not very comfortable. I like a jacket with a lot of pockets, don't you? What's the next treat going to be, hmm? What's your name?
Gatherer Hade wishes to see you.
Gatherer Hade?
He ordered your release.
What about my chum?
Just you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard helps the Doctor on with his coat, and the Doctor leaves with Marn after putting his bag of jelly babies next to Bisham's head.

Dialogue.Line: It's the next turn. About fifty yards. There's a guard on the gate.
Just one?
I have seen two, but normally there's just one.
Strange. I feel fear. Why should I be frightened? K9: There is a chemical inhibitor in the air, mistress. I have analysed it.
What does that mean, K9? K9: It means you feel fear because it affects the human nervous system and debilitates the will.
You mean there's nothing to be afraid of, just something in the air? K9: Affirmative.
Right. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Marn leads the Doctor in. Hade greets him warmly.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Citizen Doc-Tor. Welcome. Come in, sit down.
Thank you.
No, no, no. Please, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes Hade's tall backed chair.

Dialogue.Line: Citizen Doc-Tor. An unusual name.
Yes, especially for an Ajack.
Indeed. There are so many Wurgs and Keeks in Megropolis Three I sometimes wonder how my distinguished colleague, Gatherer Pile, manages to keep track of you all.
Indeed. But how very clever of you to know my name.
Well, it's here, on your ConSumCard.
Ah.
The cause of your unfortunate experience, of which I trust there are no ill effects?
Oh, not at all, not at all. Your guards were entirely charming, and so attentive.
I am gratified. I brought you here, Citizen Doc-Tor, first of all to give you the thousand talmars you requested.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Marn hands over a pouch of money.

Dialogue.Line: And also to apologise for any inconvenience. To err is computer.
To forgive is fine?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard with a massive weapon is patrolling.

Dialogue.Line: All right, K9. Bite. K9: Mistress?
Stun him. K9: Affirmative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 trundles forward. Cordo wants to watch, but Leela mouths at him to wait. The guard kindly kneels to get a better look at K9, then raises a communicator to his mouth. K9 zaps him before he can say anything. Leela runs up and pats K9, and takes the weapon. They enter the Correction Centre.
Marn is handing round refreshments from a box.

Dialogue.Line: Would you care for a leaf?
Oh, thank you, thank you. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes one and tries it. He finds it delicious.

Dialogue.Line: Rubus idaeus?
No, raspberry leaves. I have them specially imported. They contain natural chlorophyll. Very healthy.
Have you ever tasted raspberry leaf tea? Awfully good for aliments of the throat.
Is that so?
Yes.
Of course, in primitive times on Old Earth, they ate prodigious quantities of vegetable matter without any apparent harm to their system.
Remarkable.
Mmm. I'm quite a student of antiquity. Many people alive are not even aware that our species originated on Old Earth.
I can hardly credit it.
It's true. They learn nothing in the Preparation Centres.
Mind you, I've often wondered why we left Old Earth.
Ah, well, of course there is a religious view, though I've always inclined to the expansionist theory. Natural progression. Tell me, Citizen Doc-Tor, are you planning to stay long in Megropolis One?
Not long, no.
Well, while you're here, you must get about a bit. After all, it is the first and oldest city on Pluto. There's much of interest to see.
Well, I shall certainly try. In fact, I shall start right now.
Oh, don't let me detain you any longer. I know you visiting Executives have a very busy schedule. An agreeable meeting.
Humbug?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds out a paper bag. Where does he get them from?

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I am gratified.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And eats a jelly baby. The Doctor leaves, and Marn enters.

Dialogue.Line: The tracker system is keyed to him, your Honour.
Excellent. I think he swallowed my story of mechanical error without any suspicion.
He couldn't believe his luck when we gave him the thousand talmars. That was a stroke of genius, your Honour.
I think it added a touch of verisimilitude. Of course, he needed the money for a reason. Possibly to buy the services of that work-shy scum in the Undercity.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Marn switches on the monitor to follow the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Let's see where he's heading.
This door, K9? K9: Negative.
Here, K9? K9: Affirmative. The master passed through this entrance.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bisham has the headset on again, and a guard is adjusting the levers as Leela, K9 and Cordo enter. Leela shoots the guard.

Dialogue.Line: It is not him! Guard the door, K9. Help me free this one, Cordo.
Gratified, Citizens.
Listen. Listen, we're looking for the Doctor.
You are his friends?
Jelly babies!
You have seen him! Where is he?
Yes, he was here, but they set him free.
Who did? Where is he now?
I don't know. He went out with one of the Gatherer's officials.
Leela, we should go. The longer we're here
Yes. Check the corridor, K9. K9: Mistress.
Are you fit enough to move?
Yes, yes, I think so. The treatment had only just started when you came in. K9: Corridor clear, mistress.
Leela!
You'd better come with us. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Marn and Hade watch the Doctor go along a tunnel, regularly looking behind him.

Dialogue.Line: He's returning to the Undercity, your Honour. The tracker system doesn't function there.
No matter if we lose him for an hour or two underground. We can always locate him whenever he moves in the city.
But it is in the Undercity, your Honour, that the rebellion is festering.

The Collector has allocated me half a division of his Inner Retinue, Marn. They'll soon deal with that leaderless rabble. I shall send one squad in through the heating conduits to force them into the open. The other section will pick them off as they emerge.
Your Honour is a tactical genius.
I formed the plan on my way back from the Palace. I call it Morton's Fork, in honour of one of my illustrious predecessors.
Shall I alert the guards?
Not yet. Morton's Fork will stab, Marn, only when I am sure we have identified all the conspirators.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The stunned guard wakes and uses his communicator.

Dialogue.Line: Emergency. Emergency. Calling all Districts.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mealtime.

Dialogue.Line: This tastes like swill. Where'd you get this garbage?
Don't you like it, Mandrell? I'll have yours.
Listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: Suppertime? Save me some.
We heard you'd been taken.
Well, I was, I was, but it was all a misunderstanding. Gatherer apologised profusely. Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tips out the metal tokens onto the table.

Dialogue.Line: A thousand talmars.
What trick's this?
No trick. Gave me a raspberry leaf as well. Where's Leela?
She's gone.
What?
She's gone.
We heard you were in the Correction Centre. She went off with some crazy idea of getting you out.
Mandrell, you made a certain threat before I left. If anything's happened to that girl.
Don't threaten me, Doctor. The Gatherer doesn't give anyone money. He takes but he doesn't give, so you'd better have a good story.
Once upon a time there were three sisters.
I think you're a spy. A spy for the Gatherer.
The guard, he's gone!
We should have killed him. He will have raised the alarm.
Well, there's no turning back.
If we're caught in this corridor, we'll have no chance, Leela.
What do you suggest?
We must be daring. If we take the P45 return route they'll never expect to find us there.
I hope you're right, Cordo.
Come on, lead the way.
K9. K9: Mistress?
Hide. We must keep still. Make them think we will not fight.
You have a gun, Leela. Why don't you kill us?
What?
I'd rather die here than let them take us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The vehicle stops a few metres away and a guard gets out.

Dialogue.Line: Drop your arms.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela walks to the side and puts the weapon down.

Dialogue.Line: Get them, K9.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 shoots the first guard, and the second gets out of the vehicle cautiously. K9 moves forward and shoots him, too.

Dialogue.Line: Satisfactory, mistress?
Get their guns. K9: Satisfactory, mistress?
Yes, K9. What do you want, a biscuit? We will take this machine and crash through their barrier. Put K9 on the back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Around the corner, the guards at the barricade are curious.

Dialogue.Line: The shooting's stopped. Our lads must have got them. Not our lucky day.
Ready? Forward.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She puts her foot on the pedal and it goes backwards.

Dialogue.Line: Great Xoanan! I said forward!
Perhaps I'd better take over, Leela.
All right. I will have the gun.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She sits behind the vehicle mounted weapon and Bisham drives off, forward. Round the corner, the guards are dismantling the barricade.

Dialogue.Line: Bring them against this wall. That's right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela fires at them.

Dialogue.Line: Look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Firing again and again, they drive through the gap made by the guards.

Dialogue.Line: We've done it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two sides swap weapons fire, then -

Dialogue.Line: Ow!
Stop! Leela's been hit!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela is lying on the ground some way behind them now. The guards keep firing.

Dialogue.Line: We can't help her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He drives on with Cordo and K9.

Dialogue.Line: Now you're going to answer my questions, Doctor.
Good.
Why did the Gatherer give you this money?
Maybe he liked my face.
You know what I think?
Ah, that's a catch question. With a brain your size you don't think, right?
Now listen, Doctor. We can either do this the easy way

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mandrell raises his whip.

Dialogue.Line: Or we can do it the hard way. I've heard that one, too.
Get him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One of the outlaws punches the Doctor in the stomach, knocking him down.

Dialogue.Line: The Gatherer gave you a thousand talmars to bring to us?
Well, even Gatherers have their bad days.
Now this is going to be your bad day, Doctor, if you don't start talking.
About what?
The deal. You and the Gatherer made a deal.
I only made one deal, Mandrell, and that was with you under duress, and you haven't kept your part of it.
Now the irons. Another minute. Doctor, you've got one more minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mandrell turns the Doctor to see the red hot poker ready for him.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, that sort of subtle approach is always more effective than crude violence.
Oh, he's very cool.
Parts of him won't be so cool soon.
This is your last chance.

You're a fool, Mandrell. I don't know why yet, but I was released from the Correction Centre. The Gatherer gave me a cock and bull story about machine error, and he gave me a thousand talmars to make it sound convincing. That's all I know.
You'll have to do better than that, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The red hot poker, with the shape of the Megropolis logo on it, is held in front of the Doctor's face.

Dialogue.Line: You're not very good at it, Mandrell.
Talk, Doctor.
It's the eyes. No conviction.
I'm going to count to ten, Doctor. One
Oh, put it aside, Mandrell. You look a fool.
Two.
Three.
Four.
Five.
Five.
Ha!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor makes a grab for the poker as -

Dialogue.Line: Hold it, Mandrell!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bisham and Cordo have arrived, and Bisham has a weapon pointed at Mandrell.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you, gentlemen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes the poker and puts it back by the fire.

Dialogue.Line: Nice to see you both. Where's Leela? Well, where is she?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela is lying unconscious on a slab, being checked over. The Collector is there in his electric wheelchair.

Dialogue.Line: She's not numbered, Excellency.
What? All our work units are numbered at birth.
Some criminals have the number removed by surgery, but there's always a scar.
No number. A mystery to solve. Maximise her medicare. Bring her to me the moment she's on her feet.
Yes, Excellency.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector and his guards leave.

Dialogue.Line: He's asking us to help him!
No, no, he's not.
No, no, I'm not. I'm not, Goudry. I'm asking you to help yourselves. Nothing will change round here unless you change it.
We have the two guns, and there's K9 upstairs.
Two guns? What will we do with two guns against all those guards?
You can't do anything, but there are fifty million people in this city. Think how the guards will react to that number.
It's crazy talk. Rebellion? No one would support you.
Given the chance to breathe clean air for a few hours, they might. Have you thought of that?
I've thought of that, Doctor. The PCM is the source of the Company's power, but without explosives there's no way of stopping it entering the vapour chambers.
There's always a way. Come here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Bisham move aside.

Dialogue.Line: Listen, that drug is volatilized into the atmosphere. What's its critical temperature?
Two hundred and five centigrade.
Two hundred and five centigrade. So if we lower the temperature in the chamber
There are eight of them, all round the city.
What?
But all controlled from one point.
How do you know that?
I was a B grade in Main Control. The Doctor's right. It could work.
Are you out of your mind, Mandrell?
How?
You mean take over Main Control?
Yes. There are only two work units on duty up there. You're right, Doctor. It could be done.
It sounded to me like you were saying we should help!
That's what I was thinking, Goudry.
But why? It's a crazy idea.
But I think it could work. And what have we got to lose?
Only your claims.
Well put, Doctor.
Oh, it was nothing. I have a gift for the apt phrase.
Anything's worth trying. If only we could win. Just think, if we could beat the Company!
There's no if about it, Cordo. We will.
What's your plan, Doctor?
First of all we've got to blind the scanner system. At the moment it's sensitised on me, so I can't move from this spot.
What scanner system?
Well, every few metres along the subway there are tubes in the walls.
You mean the sun feeds.
No, I mean the oculoid electronic monitors. They're connected to concealed cables. Cordo, I want two of them brought here.
Right, Doctor.
Cordo?
Yes?
Take care. I mean, unplug them carefully.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Yes?
I don't think she was badly wounded.
Get this thing off me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela is hauled, bandaged round her head and in a strait-jacket, into the room.

Dialogue.Line: The terrorist, Excellency.
Let me go!
Name.
Answer his Excellency.
I will split you.
Your name!
Leela.
Place of birth.
I don't have to answer.
Place of birth.
I don't know. I'm a member of the Sevateem.
The Sevateem?
My tribe. Tell this gorilla to take his paws off me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector speaks into a microphone.

Dialogue.Line: Zero zero five on Sevateem.
Zero zero five. Sevateem. Negative report. Semantic analysis suggests linguistic corruption. Inferences degenerate unsupported Tellurian colony.
How did you get to Pluto?
By accident, as usual.
Answer respectfully!
The Doctor brought me in a machine called a Tardis, if that leaves you any the wiser.
What is the Doctor?
He is a Time Lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector beckons Leela over.

Dialogue.Line: You were in that criminal attack on the Company Correction Centre. Why?
Well, I heard the Doctor was in trouble, so I came to rescue him, but when I got here he'd been set free, so we
This interview is terminated. Remove her.
Erased, Excellency?
Not as of now. Place her under pending.
Immediately, Excellency.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He puts Leela over his shoulder and carries her out.

Dialogue.Line: Put me down!
I'll issue an invoice for erasure by close of business today. Zero zero five. The Time Lords. Specifically one known as the Doctor.
Zero zero five. Time Lords. Oligarchic rulers of the planet Gallifrey. The planet was classified grade three in the last market survey, its potential for market development being correspondingly low.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is working on the monitors that Cordo has got for him.

Dialogue.Line: It's true. If we all act together, there's nothing the Company can do.
If we all act together.
Yes, let's fight the Company.
Fight, yes.
What is this Company? Can anyone tell me that?
Well, it's just the Company.
It gave us the suns.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: General babble.

Dialogue.Line: Shush. I mean, who runs it? What's it for?
It makes a profit, that's what it's for. And the, er, Collector is a sort of high official. There's nobody else.
A profit?
Yes.
But who gets the profit? Where does it go?
Not to us.
They're not questions we've ever thought about. I mean there's no answer.
Wouldn't it be interesting to find the answer?
Well, yes, of course
Yes!
Cordo, take these. They're ready.
Right, Doctor.

Now listen. Bisham and Mandrell, stay with me. Now the rest of you, I want you to scatter through the city and tell the people what's happening. Remind them that they're human beings, and tell them that human beings always have to fight for their freedom. All right?
Right!
You all know what to do?
Yes!
Let's go.
Your Hugeness sent for me?
You ordered a prisoner to be released from Correction today. Why?
I can explain, your Amplification. He is the Ajack conspirator sent here to foment rebellion. It is my intention to follow him through the tracker system and identify his contacts.
There is no rebellion, Hade, and your so-called Ajack is an alien who landed on this planet by mistake. He is a Time Lord known as the Doctor.
But how? Your Vastness is certain?
I simply checked Company records. This Doctor could be a problem.
In what way, your Voluminousness?
He has a long history of violence and of economic subversion. He will not be sympathetic to my Company's business methods.
If there's anything I can do to help the Company? Long life the Company.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector hits a big red button and there is a screech.

Dialogue.Line: Issue hourly bulletins. Five thousand talmars reward for information leading his capture, dead or alive.
Magnificent.
The money to be paid from your private purse.
Argh!
You spoke?
Merely a cry of gladness at being so honoured.
Also, bulletin information that the Doctor's companion is to be publically executed for her crimes against the Company.
Praise the Company for ever and ever. Er, where will the execution be held?
In the Exchange Hall. Admission by ticket only, five talmars. Proceeds to the Company Benevolent Fund.
Enormity will attend?
Naturally. The execution will take place during the first work shift. Announce a two hour public holiday without pay.
The work units will cry with delight. Such generosity is unparalleled.
I compute a point oh four seven percent drop in production, which is within acceptable limits. Also, station extra security units in all the subways around the Exchange.
Extra units, your Globosity?
The computer character analysis indicates that the Doctor will try to prevent the execution. With luck, we'll roll two of them into the steamer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo finishes putting the monitor units back on the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Ready, Doctor.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor walks back and forth between the two.

Dialogue.Line: One more time, just for luck. K9: Duplication quite unnecessary.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But he does it anyway.

Dialogue.Line: Right, well that should do it.
What did you do, Doctor?
Well, I fixed a static loop, what else. Mandrell, you lead the way. Cordo second, Bisham third. K9, fifth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela is hanging from the wall at about forty five degrees, apparently unsupported, with a guard on watch. A man enters and chuckles.

Dialogue.Line: Comfortable?
Do I look it?
Shan't keep you pending long. His Excellency has invoiced your execution.
Good. That means I won't have to look at your ugly face any more.
Be a bit of a treat for us, too. We haven't had a public steaming for months.
A public what?
You don't know about the steamer?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He leaves, laughing.

Dialogue.Line: Visual scan clear, master.
One more level after this.
We've picked them up, your Honour.
Excellent. What's the location?
Service subway twenty seven, district four. I've already alerted the guards.
What? Stop them, stop them at once.
They're on live.
I must arrest him myself.
Arrest him? I thought we were to keep him under observation
All the plans have changed, Marn. The Collector wants him taken dead of alive.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hade loads a hand weapon.

Dialogue.Line: You'd better come with me as a witness. Oh, the idiot. Look at him, look at him, walking up and down where everyone could see him.
A witness?
He could cost me five thousand talmars! Hurry, woman!

Attention, Citizens. Attention all Citizens. Stand by for an important public bulletin. Have you seen this man? (The Doctor.) He is an anti-Company agent wanted for acts of terrorism. Gatherer Hade will pay a reward of five thousand talmars for information leading to the capture of the gangster, dead or alive.
Hey, five thousand.
Peanuts. It's an insult. The Droges of Gabrielides offered a whole star system for my head once.
What?
K-keep your hands wh-where we can see them.
Put your hands on your head.
Stand still. This is a rising, Citizens. Either you join us or you die.
I remember you. Mandrell.
That's right, Synge. What's your answer, B grade? Right.
You stay where you are. You can't do that!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mandrell goes to the control wall and pulls a lever down.

Dialogue.Line: It's done.
But the vapour towers.
We're shutting them down.
Yes, nasty horrid smelly things. Carry on, Cordo.
This is the nerve centre of the City, eh?
Yes, in one way it is. All the power is controlled from here.
All right, Citizens. Are you with the revolution or not?
We're with you, brothers, eh, Hackett?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hade and Marn sneak up on the corner.

Dialogue.Line: Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But the Doctor is not pacing up and down where they saw him.

Dialogue.Line: He's not there.
I don't understand.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She checks the monitors with a hand device.

Dialogue.Line: These scanners are still registering.
I don't care what the scanners say. I do care what the scanners say. Check again, Marn. There must be some malfunction.
Your Honour, the scanner information shows that the Doctor is walking up and down exactly here.
Fool!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Now Leela's picture is being shown.

Dialogue.Line: This is the gangster terrorist soon to be executed in the Exchange Hall.
It's Leela!
Tickets for the spectacle are still available.
Fetch the Doctor, quickly.
Price five talmars.
Doctor!
At the Company offices. As a special privilege, during the hours of the public holiday, the steaming will also be shown live on all bulletin screens.
The temperature in the heat exchange is down to seventy centigrade. Shall we keep it at that level, Doctor?
What?
At seventy.
What do they mean, a steaming?
Well, they put her into a condensation chamber.
It's directly underneath here.
The heat exchange is regulated by water pumps. It turns into high pressure steam, of course, and then goes into the condensation chamber.
It's a terrible death. You can hear the
Shush.
Come here, Bisham. Listen, I. Mandrell! Mandrell, what would happen if we cut the water supply to the pumps?
The heat exchanger would blow up, take half the city with it.
No, no, no, just for a few minutes. Just long enough to get her out.
You'd have to crawl through that vent in the wall to get to the condensation chamber.
Doctor, take a look.
No, it couldn't be done. You can see what the atmospheric pressure in there is. It would flatten you.
So we let that pressure out.
You couldn't do it.
Why not?
It's a safety system.
The only way would be to open the valve from the inside.
And inside, you're dead. It's impossible. K9: Suggestion, master.
What? What is it? K9: As my construction offers more resistance to pressure than the human frame
Yes, yes. K9: It may be that I could function inside the vent?
Yes, but could you open a valve? K9: I could attempt to blast it, master.
Attempt to blast. We'll try it. Get that vent open.
Bisham!
K9, I don't know how to say this, K9. K9: Master, your concern is noted. Please do not embarrass me.
Good dog.
Look, it's starting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the screen, Leela is struggling against her bonds

Dialogue.Line: Are we ready?
Almost, your Mightiness. We won't be long.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A cage is placed over Leela.

Dialogue.Line: A poor turnout, Hade.
Five talmars for only one execution. If we could have offered more victims, made a bigger show of it. Of course, when they can see it all for nothing on the bulletin screens
Not the same thing at all. No sense of a shared experience. I fear the Doctor is going to disappoint us. Your scanners haven't detected him?
Er, not exactly.
What does that mean? Either they have or they haven't.
Well, er, the truth of the matter is, there's a fault in the system. A false image. But I can assure your Sublimity it'll soon be rectified.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hade wilts under the Collector's Look.
An indicator plummets to zero.

Dialogue.Line: K9's done it. Look!
Get the vent open.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bisham obeys.

Dialogue.Line: Mandrell, reverse the pumps.
Pumps in reverse.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 comes out of the vent.

Dialogue.Line: We'll give you two minutes, Doctor. We can't give you any longer.
I know, I know. Well done, K9. K9: It was nothing, master.
Take this, Doctor. It's a two way communicator. If anything goes wrong, you can let us know.
All right. Now, don't call me. You understand? I'll call you.
Right. And Doctor? Two minutes!
Good luck, Doctor.
Good luck, Doctor! K9: Good luck, master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor vanishes into the vent.

Dialogue.Line: Temperature in the Exchange room is rising fast, Mandrell. I don't think we can hold it for two minutes.
We must. I told him two minutes.
The execution! She's going into the steamer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela's cage is sent running down a set of tracks.

Dialogue.Line: This is the moment I get a real feeling of job satisfaction. Are the microphones wired in?
All round the condenser, most Merciful. We're looking forward to excellent duodecaphonic sound.
Then we shall hear within a few seconds.
That noise, Hade. Can't something be done about it? We shan't hear her.
It's vibration in the exchanger, your Magnificence.
I know what it is. I don't want my pleasure ruined by it.
Her cries will be clearly audible, your Honour.
What's that? The subtleties will be lost. The deeper notes of despair, the final dying cadences. The whole point of a good steaming is the range it affords.
Marn. Er, no. I'll see if the discriminator can be adjusted, your Immensity.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters the Condensation chamber and goes over to Leela, who is lying rather still. He opens the cage, covers her mouth to keep her quiet, and starts unfastening her.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, can you hear me?
I can't give you any longer.
The exchanger's going to blow any second.
Get out, Doctor. Get out of there!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor finishes unfastening Leela and they go into the vent. Hade reenters the Hall.

Dialogue.Line: What was it?
I thought I heard someone say Doc-Tor, your Sagacity. It wasn't the girl. There hasn't been a peep out of her.
Precisely, Hade. Something has gone wrong. Order the guards to investigate.
Immediately, your Omniscience. Come along, Marn!
Flow valves open.
Main pumps in.
Sixty atmospheres, still rising.
Plug auxiliaries in. Quick!
Auxiliaries in. She's cooling, look.
We've made it. Unless the air plates have buckled, Synge.
Let's hope they haven't.
Do you think the Doctor got out in time?
If he didn't, he wouldn't have known much about it.
We gave him his two minutes. More than his two minutes.
Listen. In the vent! He's made it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They run to the hatch and open it.

Dialogue.Line: Leela!
Who was making all that noise?
I was, Doctor.
I told you not to use that radio link.
We had to tell you that your time was up, Doctor.
You told the Collector, too! That fish-blooded sadist had Leela's casket wired for sound.
What's happening? What's he doing here?
We've sired a revolution, Leela. Down with the Company, eh, fellas!
Ah, ah, Cordo. We've got a great deal to do yet.
It's going well, though, Doctor.
Is it?
The PCM is clearing from the air faster than I expected. It's down ten points already.
All my men are out putting some fight into the work units. If just one District joins the resistance the word'll spread through the whole City.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the screen, the guard Commander is whispering in the Collector's ear.

Dialogue.Line: Shush. Where's the public video system controlled from?
The Collector's Palace.
Yes, he runs everything from the Computer room. Why, Doctor?
If the public video system announced there'd been a successful rebellion, think of the effect.
Everyone would believe it.
Right.
Yes, but the Palace is guarded by his Inner Retinue.
He's guarded by his Inner Retinue, and most of them are down there with him. Come on, Leela, let's go.
MegroGuards! MegroGuards coming this way!
Everybody keep calm, keep calm. Keep quiet. You two back there. You three over there. Leela, behind the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two blue uniformed guards enter.

Dialogue.Line: What do you want here?
All right, drop your guns.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor finds handcuffs in a pocket.

Dialogue.Line: All right, tie them up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mandrell and Leela takes the guards away.

Dialogue.Line: Pretty soon the whole place will be under siege here. K9? (to Bisham) I want you to hold out as long as possible.
Yes, Doctor.
We'll do it, Doctor.
Of course you will.
Now we have more weapons, we can hold the corridor.
Good man. K9?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: K9 appears.

Dialogue.Line: K9, where are you? K9: Master.
Ah, there you are. Now, listen. I want you to give my friends all the help they need. You understand? K9: I am at full offensive capability, master.
You're a good dog. Come on, Leela. Gentlemen, good luck.
Thank you, Doctor.
Right, Doctor.
An unprofitable operation, Hade.
Your Supernal Eminence, I simply can't understand it. No one has ever endured a steaming without vocalising in the most gratifying fashion.
A complete waste of time. And we've lost point oh four seven percent in production. Unpaid overtime to be introduced immediately for all work grades. See to it!
Without fail, Monstrosity, without fail.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard enters.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
Your Excellence, sir. Some minor disturbances. It may not be wise to travel in the subways until the trouble has been suppressed.
What trouble?
It appears that some of the work units are refusing to leave their dormers, Excellency.
Refusing to leave? I've never heard of such a thing.
This situation must be normalised. Any sustained unrest among the workforce will adversely affect Company profitability.
Sing adoration to our Company!
I have dispatched a division of the retinue, Excellency. The account will be swiftly settled.
With interest, Commander. They must be made to pay.
I will introduce a swingeing output linked penalty tax in my next monthly budget, your Corpulence.
The Doctor must be behind it. I sense the vicious doctrine of egalitarianism, Hade.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He starts going round in small circles.

Dialogue.Line: Everyone knows your senses are infallible, your Promontory.
Have the guards reported from Main Control yet?
No, your Omnipresence. My underling Marn is investigating.
Not good enough, Hade. Not good enough. I am noting your work rate.
I will instigate action myself, your Aggrandizement. Instantly. Immediately.
You'll never believe this, Bisham, but I'm really beginning to enjoy myself.
The air's better without PCM, isn't it.
Yes, we'll never pay breathing tax to the Company again.
Oh, we'll pay no more taxes, brother. The Gatherer's got his last talmar off of us.
I feel so good, like a new man!
Keep an eye on the corridor, Cordo, or you'll be a dead new man.
All right, Mandrell. I know. K9's got it covered.
I wonder what's happening in the subways and dormers?
Theoretically, the dispersion rate of the PCM should be slower down there, but there should be something happening by now.
If the work units turn, the guard'll really have their hands full.
Come on, move yourselves. Report for work at once. Work! Work!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The work units make rebellious noises.

Dialogue.Line: Collector's orders.
Strike, brother. Join us, or get out.
Who said that? Who was it?
Me. Nobody works today.
Nobody works today.
That's mutiny against the Company. You've just earned yourself an early death day, Citizen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Goudry and Veet laugh as the work units easily overpower and disarm the guard.
A guard goes rolling tip over point into the room, and Leela follows with her knife raised.

Dialogue.Line: No, no, no.
Why not?
No, don't kill him. He hasn't done you any harm.
Then I shall kill him before he does.
No. Get up. Come on, get up.
Doctor, the last one I spared got away and warned his comrades. That is why I was captured.

Then we'll make sure this one doesn't get away. Here, look at me. Look at me! Now listen. It's your sleep time. Sleep time. You're feeling very sleepy. Very sleepy. It's your sleep time. You will go to sleep and stay asleep until I tell you to wake up. Until I tell you to wake up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor successfully hypnotises the guard, and Leela.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He realises, and covers the guards ears.

Dialogue.Line: Wake up.
How did you do that?
What, that? Poof, it's just a knack. You've either got it or you haven't.
Doctor!
What is it?
This is where the grey one, the Collector, sat.
What, like a spider in the middle of a web?
Yes, yes.

I understand all this. He has a computer feeding and analysing the daily returns from each Megropolis. Suppose. Suppose he wants to broadcast some pleasing bit of news, hmm? Like the imposition of a double vision tax on people with more than one eye. Well, then, he feeds it into there.
He fed it into here.
He did?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hade runs in.

Dialogue.Line: I fear the situation is worsening, your Grossness.
Laxity, Hade, laxity and weakness. You have shown them too much kindness. A grave error of judgment. Grinding oppression of the masses is the only policy that pays dividends.
Your Oratundity, my MegroGuards are outnumbered by the rabble. If I could have two divisions of the Inner Retinue?
The sole task of the Inner Retinue is to protect my person. You've mishandled the situation, Hade. As for your ambition to become Tax Master General. After this, forget it!
Your Honour.
What is it, Marn?
I've just heard that some of the work units have gone to the roof of Block Forty to look at our sun.
Outrageous! Sacrilege! The work units are absolutely forbidden to see the light of the sun. It's far too good for them. I'll soon deal with this.
A combat situation is escalating. Those idiots have let it get out of hand. It is imperative that I return to the Palace to implement my contingency plans.
But Excellency, there's fighting in the
Quiet! The Inner Retinue will march around me in close order. Their bodies will shield me. Now hurry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has been examining the workings underneath the Collector's desk, and followed a lead to the big red button.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, come here.
That should do it.
Doctor! What is this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A big wall with a large dial on it.

Dialogue.Line: What, that? It's a safe. Company vault.
Doctor, is there
Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He listens to the door as he turns the dial.

Dialogue.Line: Is there something behind the door?
What was that?
I heard nothing.
Neither did I.
Then why are we whispering?
I always whisper when I'm opening safes. What is it?
What are you doing?
I don't know. It always looks so easy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stands back and aims his sonic screwdriver at it. The mechanism clicks away to itself, then the big handle turns. The Doctor pulls the metre- thick D shaped door open. They look inside.

Dialogue.Line: Why was it locked?
I don't know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela and the Doctor try to go in at the same time, but the doorway is too narrow. They walk away, then Leela turns to run in. An energy field catches her and she falls to the floor. The Doctor looks for, finds and presses a small button before stepping through himself.

Dialogue.Line: Why won't you listen to me? Why don't you girls listen to me?
The PCM in the atmosphere has fallen to three parts in a thousand.

Attention all Citizens. Attention all Citizens. Stand by for an important public bulletin. Megropolis One is now under the management of the Citizen's Revolution. The Director, the Tax Gatherer and all other Company officials are to be arrested on sight.
It's happened.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Marn is listening to the announcement.

Dialogue.Line: All guards are ordered to lay down their arms and join their fellow Citizens in peaceful cooperation.
There! Stop or we fire. Get her!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Marn draws her gun, then with a smile, offers it to them.

Dialogue.Line: Citizens, I'd like to join the Revolution.
The rule of the Company is ended. All work places will remain closed until further notice. Long live the Revolution.
Whee!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And fires at the ceiling. Mandrell and Bisham hit the floor.

Dialogue.Line: It's over!
Cordo!
We've won!
We haven't.
What?
That bulletin was fixed. It was the Doctor trying to push things on a bit.
That'll bring the whole city onto our side. I don't know why you're hesitating.
Yes! We've got the guns, we should get out and help them.
What do you think, Bisham?
Cordo's right. The fight has moved on from here.
Synge. You can run things down here.
I suppose so, but leave K9 guarding the corridor, just in case, eh?
Yes, of course.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Various people are lounging about round the Tardis, sunbathing.

Dialogue.Line: You there! What are you scum doing up here? This is an abominable crime. An outrage! Leave at once, do you hear me?
It's the Gatherer. It's the Gatherer!
I order you to leave. You'll pay dearly. Keep back! Don't you dare! I'm an official of the Company!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The people lift up the Gatherer, run him to the edge and throw him over without ceremony, cheering him all the way down.

Dialogue.Line: And we'll do the same for the Collector when we find him, won't we, Citizens.
Yes!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector trundles in, pausing briefly at the sleeping guard before going to his desk. In the strongroom, the Doctor hears him and puts back a small block he was examining from the array of blocks around the wall and walks out.

Dialogue.Line: Kindly make less noise.
Oh, I was just checking the books.
Your appearance is not unexpected.
I'm not the Auditor, I'm the Doctor.
I know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector reaches for his red button. The Doctor is holding up a steel chair.

Dialogue.Line: If you intend to kill me, as you see, I'm unarmed.
No, I won't kill you. Just close you down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts the chair down and sits on it.

Dialogue.Line: An idle boast. Other competitors have tried. Would you care to see our prospectus?
Oh, delighted, delighted.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector hands over a folder.

Dialogue.Line: Hmm. Company solidly based. You've a widely diversified operational field. Yes.
You're a fool, Doctor. I shall have you steamed for your interference.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector hits his red button. It bounces out and the Doctor catches it.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I cut the answering service not to interrupt our little conference.
Very well. I see I underestimated you. What are your terms?
Tell me about the Company.
Ah, you're interested.
Yes.
Oh, an excellent outfit to work for, Doctor. Progress from medium to senior management level can be remarkably rapid for the talented executive.
Yes, cut the sales talk. Where's the Head Office?
Usurius.
Ah. I might have guessed from your squiddy little eyes. Hmm.
You are acquainted with our species?
Oh yes, oh yes. The Usurians are listed in Professor Thripsted's Flora and Fauna of the Universe under poisonous fungi.
I don't entirely like your attitude. If you want to get on in the Company you have to what? What? Are you mad?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor rips off the printout and reads it.

Dialogue.Line: Quite mad. Mad as a hatter.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He screws up the paper and throws it away.

Dialogue.Line: Tell me, how did you get control of humanity?
A normal business operation. The Company was looking for property in this sector, Earth was running down, it's people dying. We made a deal.
Go on.
Yes. We moved them all to Mars.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela starts to wake.

Dialogue.Line: After our engineers had made that planet habitable for their species.
And then taxed the life out of them. I mean, to recover your capital costs.
Quite so, quite so. Then, when the resources of Mars were exhausted in their turn, we created a new environment for them here on Pluto.
Phew. What about the four intervening planets?
They weren't considered viable by our engineers.
So then you really put the screws on. I mean, the running costs must be very high.
Six suns to be fueled and serviced.
Six suns. Six! My, my. And so when this planet's exhausted you can move your slave labour force elsewhere?
Alas, no. There is nowhere else that is economic. This branch will close.
Leaving the humans to die.
When the suns have run down, yes. A matter of a few years without fuel. They're not a good workforce in any case. Many of our other operations produce a much higher return with less labour.
You blood-sucking leech! You won't stop until you own the entire galaxy, will you. Don't you think commercial imperialism is as bad as military conquest?
We have tried war, but the use of economic power is far more effective.
You

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sounds of weapons fire come close.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. The revolution's getting nearer. What's the Company policy on that?
It will be quelled. Business will continue as usual.
Oh, wake up. Wake up. Look at the facts.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard wakes up as instructed.

Dialogue.Line: I know the facts.
You and a handful of bureaucrats won't put the people back in chains now.
Then they will die.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard puts his hand weapon to the back of the Doctor's neck.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's you again. What did I say?
Our conference has gone on too long, Doctor. It is time to implement contingency plan A.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector goes to a computer panel, opens it and reaches for a lever. The Doctor laughs.

Dialogue.Line: This switch controls the sprinkler valves throughout the City.
Rain stops play. I don't think that'll damp down this revolution.
The sprinklers will release dianene, a deadly poison. Within ten seconds, everyone in the City will be dead.
Except you.
Exactly. I do not breathe air.
No, but this chap at my shoulder, he breathes air.
Kill him!
Don't be a fool.
Guard, kill him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard puts his gun to the Doctor's head and Leela throws her knife, getting him in the right shoulder.

Dialogue.Line: Good throw! Good throw.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela runs round and slams the panel door hard against the Collector's hand.

Dialogue.Line: What's contingency plan B?
Nobody understands business is business.
What do we do now, Doctor, kill him?
You'll like this bit. You'll like it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector speaks into his intercom.

Dialogue.Line: Nine zero nine! A mistake in the Megropolis Six analysis. Recheck!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector's skin is turning green.

Dialogue.Line: Nine zero nine. Recheck. Megropolis Six analysis confirmed correct.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Guards run in as the Doctor laughs.

Dialogue.Line: Commander! Arrest these idiots. I have a problem. Nine zero nine. Megropolis Four analysis. Mistake. Recheck

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo and Mandrell enter.

Dialogue.Line: Nine zero nine.
Collector, in the name of the work units, I order
People, Cordo.
Yes. In the name of the people I order you to be tried by
Cordo, I don't think he's listening.
Negative surplus. Inflationary spiral uncheckable. Negative growth! This branch is no longer viable.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Collector shrinks.

Dialogue.Line: We are bankrupt. Business failure. Closure imperative. Cut losses. Liquidate. Immediate liquidation.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The tiny green collector vanishes down a hole in his wheelchair. Bisham runs in.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry I'm late. What happened?
Well, I don't know.
I do. He's gone back to his natural form. He was only held in that state by particle radiation. That's why he never left that machine.
You mean he's in there now?
Oh, yes.
Well, we could make a hole in it.
Do you think he'll come out again?
Well, you could put the plug in if you want.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cordo plugs the hole.

Dialogue.Line: I don't understand. Why was it necessary for him to make himself look human?
Well, if you'd seen a Usurian you'd know what I mean. They look like sea kale with eyes. I mean, would you take orders from a lump of seaweed? Huh? Hmm? Cordo?
Leela, let K9 in the Tardis. Goodbye, Cordo.
I wish you could stay, Doctor. There is much to do.
Well, I'll pop back and see you again when you've settled again on Earth.
That'll be hard work.
Well, you're used to hard work. This time, you'll be free.
Goodbye, Veet.
Goodbye.
Till the next time? Come on, K9. Come on.
You really believe we can colonise the Earth again?
Well, I do, I do. The Earth will have regenerated itself since you left. Get back to your place under your own sun.
Goodbye, Doctor.
Can the star freighters make that journey?
Course they will. Three hundred million of you can't go wrong. Goodbye everyone!
Goodbye.
King to Bishop four, mistress.
Which is more than I can say for the Tardis.
Eh?
Nothing. I was just finishing a thought. Now, where were we? K9: Mate in six moves, master.
Oh, be quiet, K9.
I wonder why the Collector gave in so easily? I thought he would fight.
He got a bit of a shock. You see, I fed two percent growth tax into the computers. Index linked. Blew the economy and he couldn't take it.
I do not understand. You did something clever?
Well, I. What do you think, K9? K9: Affirmative.
K9 thinks it was clever.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis tilts. Leela, the hat stand and of course the chess pieces all go flying.

Dialogue.Line: I am so sorry, K9. K9: Apologies are not necessary.
No, shut up while I apologise. I am so. Listen. As soon as I've reset the coordinates, we'll finish that game of chess.
